subject: RE: [junit] Testing getXXX( ) and setXXX( ) methods
msgSnippet: Nope... perfectly serious. I tend to copy and paste my getX() and setX() methods to save typing, then do search and replaces to set the variable names (lazy...
messageBody:
Nope... perfectly serious. I tend to copy and paste my getX() and
setX() methods to save typing, then do search and replaces to set the
variable names (lazy... or just efficiently using my time? you decide ;).
Sometimes I goof and access/mutate the wrong thing. It happens, and my test
cases have helped me to find my errors a few times.

Plus, I just don't like idea of "Write JUnit test cases for all
accessable methods... except for the really simple ones."

-tim

-----Original Message-----
From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbr@...]
Sent: Thursday, May 02, 2002 2:41 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] Testing getXXX( ) and setXXX( ) methods


Quoting "Stevens, Timothy J. (LNG-MBC)" <timothy.j.stevens@...>:

>
> Can't break!!?? You never make typos and return the wrong variable
> in a getter, or set the wrong variable in a setter? If so, you're a
> better
> coder than me :)

I hope this was tongue-in-cheek. I don't think I have *ever* returned the
wrong
variable from a getX() method[1]. In order to make this mistake, I'd have to
be
drunk. As for setting the wrong variable in a setX() method, see my previous

message. I've made that mistake exactly once.

Folks, don't test the getX() and setX() methods; but rather test that the
constructor stores the appropriate parameter in the appropriate field. I
know
I'm about 100 times more likely to write a bug there than in the getX() or
setX
() method itself.

J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
President, Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com
Let's write software that people understand.

[1] Note that I'm ignoring cases where the compiler caught a typo.
